I cried in the bathroom, skipped school, and thought about disappearing. But then I figured something out: they weren't just doing it to me—they were doing it to anyone they could. I wasn’t special, I was just convenient.

So I stopped being convenient. I started watching them. Learning their secrets. Their weaknesses. I found out about the girl who had a restraining order from her ex, the boy who stole from his parents, the popular ones who cheated on tests. And I didn’t just keep it to myself. I posted it. Not in a way that was cruel for the sake of cruelty, but in a way that made them feel exactly what I felt. The fear. The helplessness. The shame.

It wasn’t just revenge—it was power. I didn’t need to be the victim anymore. I became the one they feared. The one who could ruin them with a single post. And when they stopped coming after me, I didn’t feel guilty. I felt free.

Now, I don’t just sit back and let people walk over each other. I see someone being targeted, and I ask myself: what are their secrets? What do they fear? And I help them learn the same lesson I did. Because the moment you realize that pain can be a tool, you stop being a victim. You become something else.

Stronger.

More real.

More in control.
